description: From Middle English revers, from Anglo-Norman revers, Middle French revers, and their source, Latin reversus, perfect passive participle of reversō, from re- + versō. Doublet of revers.

entries.meaning: Opposite, contrary; going in the opposite direction. [from 14th c.]
examples: We ate the meal in reverse order, starting with dessert and ending with the starter.
The mirror showed us a reverse view of the scene.

entries.meaning: Pertaining to engines, vehicle movement etc. moving in a direction opposite to the usual direction. [from 19th c.]
(rail transport, of points) To be in the non-default position; to be set for the lesser-used route.
Turned upside down; greatly disturbed.
(botany) Reversed.
(genetics) In which cDNA synthetization is obtained from an RNA template.
(now rare) In a reverse way or direction; in reverse; upside-down. [from 16thc. (from the 14thc. in Middle English)]
examples: The man was killed to feed his image fat / Within this pictured world that ran reverse, / Where miracles alone were ever plain.

entries.meaning: The opposite of something. [from 14th c.]
examples: We believed the Chinese weren't ready for us. In fact, the reverse was true.

entries.meaning: The act of going backwards; a reversal. [from 15th c.]
examples: By a reverse of fortune, Stephen becomes rich.

entries.meaning: A piece of misfortune; a setback. [from 16th c.]
examples: In fact, though the Russians did not yet know it, the British had met with a reverse.

entries.meaning: (numismatics) The tails side of a coin, or the side of a medal or badge that is opposite the obverse. [from 17th c.]
The side of something facing away from a viewer, or from what is considered the front; the other side. [from 18th c.]
The gear setting of an automobile that makes it travel backwards. [from 19th c.]
A thrust in fencing made with a backward turn of the hand; a backhanded stroke.
(surgery) A turn or fold made in bandaging, by which the direction of the bandage is changed.

description: From Middle English reversen, from Anglo-Norman reverser, Middle French reverser, and their source, Latin reversō, from re- + versō.

verbs.description: reverse (third-person singular simple present reverses, present participle reversing, simple past and past participle reversed)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To turn something around so that it faces the opposite direction or runs in the opposite sequence.
examples: to reverse the order of books on a shelf
to reverse a portion of video footage

entries.meaning: (transitive) To turn something inside out or upside down.
examples: A pyramid reversed may stand upon his point if balanced by admirable skill.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To transpose the positions of two things.
(transitive) To change totally; to alter to the opposite.
(obsolete, intransitive) To return, come back.
(obsolete, transitive) To turn away; to cause to depart.
(obsolete, transitive) To cause to return; to recall.
(law) To revoke a law, or to change a decision into its opposite.
examples: to reverse a judgment, sentence, or decree

entries.meaning: (ergative, transport) To cause a mechanism to operate or move in the opposite direction to normal; to drive a vehicle in the direction the driver has the back.
(chemistry) To change the direction of a reaction such that the products become the reactants and vice-versa.
(rail transport, transitive) To place (a set of points) in the reverse position.
(rail transport, intransitive, of points) To move from the normal position to the reverse position.
(aviation, transitive) To engage reverse thrust on (an engine).
To overthrow; to subvert.
examples: Custom  […]  reverses even the distinctions of good and evil.

entries.meaning: (computing) Short for reverse-engineer.
examples: Reversing is also heavily used in connection with malicious software, on both ends of the fence:  […]
